definitions.definition: to mention or use a law, rule, etc. as a reason for doing something

examples.text: It is unlikely that libel laws will be invoked.

definitions.definition: to mention a person, a theory, an example, etc. to support your opinions or ideas, or as a reason for something

examples.text: She invoked several eminent scholars to back up her argument.

definitions.definition: to mention somebody’s name to make people feel a particular thing or act in a particular way

examples.text: His name was invoked as a symbol of the revolution.

definitions.definition: to make a request (for help) to somebody, especially a god
to make somebody have a particular feeling or imagine a particular scene

examples.text: The opening paragraph invokes a vision of England in the early Middle Ages.

definitions.definition: to begin to run a program, etc.

examples.text: This command will invoke the HELP system.

definitions.definition: to make evil appear by using magic

wordOrigin: late 15th cent.: from French invoquer, from Latin invocare, from in- ‘upon’ + vocare ‘to call’.
